node.note:
This is a backlog of styles, components and patterns being developed for the GOV.UK Design System.

**[How to contribute](https://github.com/alphagov/govuk-design-system-backlog/blob/master/docs/CONTRIBUTING.md)**

Items that have been proposed for the Design System. [Find out more](https://github.com/alphagov/govuk-design-system-backlog/blob/master/docs/CONTRIBUTING.md#proposing-new-styles-components-or-patterns)

content.title: Ask users for a photo of themself
content.bodyHTML:
Description

Many services need a photo of the user.

Users can take a photo with their webcam as part of their application, or upload a digital photograph of themselves. Uploading a photo may be complicated for some users, so the service should find the right route for them with a series of questions.

Note: In the future it will hopefully be possible to use HMPO's passport photos instead of this.

User needs

Users are required to upload a photo of themselves for their bus pass. The easiest way for most users to do this is by taking a photo with their device.

Examples

I've documented the pattern as used in the concessionary travel service.

This pattern is being used by DfT in the Apply for a blue badge Alpha.

Research

The research on this pattern is documented here.

Code

All of relevant HTML is here. (Sorry I haven't organised it better).

js file 1
js file 2

content.bodyHTML:
Description

content.title: Accordion
content.bodyHTML:
Description

Accordions hide the contents of a section until the user clicks on the section header.
Use them to help people quickly navigation to a section on a page that's relevant to them.

Examples

The section pages in the GOV.UK Service Manual use accordions

Research

Blog post: Designing new navigation elements for GOV.UK

Guidance

Read the draft guidance on Dropbox Paper

Code

No component code has been developed yet.

content.title: Alerts
content.bodyHTML:
Description

An on-screen alert to notify users that something important has happened.

For example:

  • an action was successful
  • an action was not sucessful
  • a deadline is imminent
  • a payment is overdue

Examples

  • Alerts and notifications: DWP design patterns
  • Overdue: HMRC design patterns
  • Alerts: Rural Payments Styleguide

Research

None available yet

Guidance

None available yet

Code

None available yet

content.title: Intro panel
content.bodyHTML:
AKA: hero banner, slide, blue panel, Introducing a service, Intro pages, Masthead, Jumbotron, interruption card, interstitial page

Description

Typically used to introduce users to new or unfamiliar concepts. Their effectiveness is partly based on their unexpected appearance so they should be used very sparingly.

Guidance

  • Interruption card: Home Office design system

content.bodyHTML:
Description

When and how to ask about people's gender and sex.

content.title: Start page
content.bodyHTML:
Description

The first page of a service on GOV.UK. Helps users understand:

  • who the service is for
  • what the service helps you do
  • what you need to do to use it
  • alternative channels to access it

Example

Example of a start page on GOV.UK

content.title: Warning text
content.bodyHTML:
Description

Use warning text to warn users about something they need to know, such as legal consequences of an action, or lack of action, that they might take.

Guidance

Read the draft guidance in Google Docs
